text: Labor's deputy leader has declared the party lost the vote of working Australians at the May election because Bill Shorten was offering "handouts rather than hope". In a speech in Melbourne, Richard Marles called on the party to "stake out the political centre" by promising working-class people a better life if they work hard instead of offering welfare and subsidies. The ALP's election loss kicked off a round of soul-searching about the party's future policy direction, with a campaign review due to be finalised next week. Image: News Corp Australia
